everal other females. =C2=A0He bows his head in submission, knowing that he=

ful. =C2=A0He sits down, to wait until he's allowed to see Talon.

really should be in there with her, but if this is their way of life, I can=

r, pops her head out and senses that Talon is in need of her protective ser=

rs and grasses.  Tucson is gently nudged outside since males are not allowe=
d inside until after the birth.  He waits outside with another older dragon=
.

if it is a physical being, it must be stopped. And I have a feeling that pe=
rhaps its best if I face this being personally. Now, let's see... This pict=
ograph gives a location.. Ah, I got it, these paintings resemble a path tha=
t I happen to know rather well. And some of this writing.. I think it means=
 " Blight" . Tucson to base, over. I have identified an enemy, via pictogra=
ph images found on my location. The name of our new enemy is Blight, and by=

> > > > > > =
> > > >

shoulders.
> > > > > > > > > > 
> > > > > > > > > > " So will I. Talon, so =
will I. But that doesn't mean we can't try to recreate a little portion of =
life on our own planet. This seed we were given, it needs soil, water, ligh=
t and something to plant it in. Perhaps we can find a place where there is =
an abundance of soil and take that with us. "
> > > > > > > > > > 
> > > > =
> > > > > > Just as he spoke, a Protohuman, carrying an offering of fish, k=
neels down before Tucson and Talon. Tucson looks to the offering. It was a =
most generous portion of fish. Yet now he could not eat it, but he knew Tal=
on would need nourishment. He nods gently to the Protohuman and accepts his=
 offering with a gentile touch of his nose on the man's shoulder. He allows=
 him to stroke his snout as some sort of good luck ritual. The man bows in =
graciousness to Tucson's gesture of kindness and leaves him be with Talon.
=
> > > > > > > > > > 
> > > > > > > > > > " I'm not so sure what all of that=
 meant but, whatever it was, it was a very kind gesture on his part. I wond=
er if these people had any interaction with the old Silver Dragon.. " 
> > =
> > > > > > > > 
> > > > > > > > > > It isn't long before others come to of=
fer more gifts to him and Talon. One of the Protohumans points to a paintin=
g on a rock, with white portraying silver, in a primitive image of a large =
reptile with outstretched wings.
> > > > > > > > > > 
> > > > > > > > > > "=
 Oh, I see now.. Yes, they have seen him before. To them he is a guardian, =
and the more offerings they gave him, he would return their kind gestures b=
y offering his protection. But there is more to these paintings.. A strange=
 mysterious figure, with an aura around it.. To me it seems evil. Another i=
dol, someone else to worship. .. People portrayed in black and white.. Whit=
e, meaning those who look to the Silver Dragon and black to those who worsh=
ip the intimidating idol.. I've seen ancient pictographs before on Cybertro=
n, and these are different but in the same format. Talon if the dragon is a=
 physical being, then this dark idol must be as well. We need to find it, b=
efore it lays harm to anyone."

> > > > > > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > >=
 > > > > With a gentile smile, Tucson returns the kiss and holds his wing o=
ver them to provide a moment alone with Talon. After the kiss he lowers his=
 wing and notices that a collection of small creatures surrounding him and =
Talon . Yet they do so in a fashion of admiration rather than hostility. Tu=
cson looks to them curiously.
> > > > > > > > > > > > 
> > > > > > > > > > =
> > " I'm not sure why these creatures are curious about us but it appears =
as if they're here to admire rather than attack. I wonder... "
> > > > > > =
> > > > > > 
> > > > > > > > > > > > He stands up and gets back into beast =
mode, and sits down once more. The creatures draw closer to him and sit bes=
ide him and Talon. It was clear that the Silver Dragon was a source of comf=
ort to these creatures, but that was about to change once he and Talon left=
 for Cybertron. It was a massive guilt slammed upon his heart. Yet how coul=
d he get the animals to understand that he had to leave them in such a shor=
t time? He was now their guardian and they were looking up to him for prote=
ction. 
> > > > > > > > > > > > 
> > > > > > > > > > > > " Talon, these cre=
atures remember the old dragon that sought to their protection and realize =
that I have taken his place. It's as I thought, they aren't aware of who we=
 really are, and where we are from. They will not understand that we must l=
eave them shortly, for good, and Primus knows what will happen to them once=
 we leave. ... Talon, I hear something coming. It's not a Predacon but it's=
 a fairly large creature."
> > > > > > > > > > > > 
> > > > > > > > > > > >=
 Not far from them, Tucson spots the scales of a rather large reptile, that=
 appears to be fishing in the stream next to them. He watches attentively a=
nd at that moment, the creature lifts its head. It was another dragon. Yet =
this one was a bit smaller than he was, but the same coloration. He takes n=
ote of its slender shape. It was female. She looks to him as he looks to he=
r. She slowly approaches him and they look gently to each other like brothe=
r and sister. In draconic vocalization, Tucson explains who he is and his d=
ilemma. She intern rumbles back and bows her head. She nods as he does. It =
was their way of communicating as Tucson looks back to Talon.
> > > > > > >=
 > > > > > 
> > > > > > > > > > > > " Apparently the old dragon has family =
here. They are scattered but they exist. And she said that she will protect=
 these creatures and this land along with her brethren for as long as they =
live. And she wishes us good luck on our journey."
> > > > > > > > > > > > =

> > > > > > > > > > > > With that, the dragoness leaves them peacefully to=
 enjoy their time together. With a gentile groan, the creatures too, depart=
. It was truly a spiritual moment for both of them.

> > > > =
> > > > > > > > > > " Like a branch on a tree that has broken off during a =
storm and regrows in a different direction than it had been, before it had =
broken off. I know exactly how you feel. I feel the same way. At one time, =
I was blind, rolled on four wheels and I always seemed to be an Autobot reb=
el. I fought along side with my comrades but I wasn't good at following ord=
ers. I was well grounded but lost at the same time. Then, I met you and thi=
ngs began to change on a more positive note. You may not believe this, but =
you helped me to find my path, and you saw me on the right road and guided =
me to my true fate. Soon afterwards, I became a Prime, acquired seventeen m=
ore wheels, and almost looked like Optimus Prime, yet different. But one th=
ing didn't change, I was still battling blindness off and on. Then, a third=
 change, due to extensive damage to my previous form, which could not be re=
paired, I was guided to my final evolution, this one. All of
>  these thing=
s wouldn't have come about if I had never met you. And I wouldn't have it a=
ny other way. Talon, I will miss this planet as much as you are, and hopefu=
lly we can tell our offspring all about this planet and it's wondrous varie=
ties of life that live here."

ers to him.

 is for us to keep? Thank you, we will take good care of it."

nd.

ave a way to bring back a small reminder of this planet. Let's see if we ca=
